subject: Satisfy API Reference documentation deleting tags

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thank Ian. Looks good to me now.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I agree that this is the correct way to fix this -- even though it is changing the actual API response code.  The response code should be consistent with the other delete response codes, so I believe the correct thing to do here is to modify the code to return a 204.  (The alternative would be to modify the api-ref to reflect the current 200 response.)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I was really surprised by this patch.
This change seems don't take care of APPs which check current status code(200) as its success operation at all.
This is really backwards incompatible changes without any notification, and it is possible to affect its interoperability.

Patch Set 2:

yea, as per guidelines it is unacceptable - https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/evaluating_api_changes.html

What ever we return in status code we have to live. We have lot of bad success code in API but we have to maintain those as per backward compatibility. 

From bug i was expecting glance team to notice this and change api-ref and if API,then with recoverability mechanism.

Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/evaluating_api_changes.html#guidance

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The API is authoritative. I feel like it is safer to change the docs to match the API in this case.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I really wonder about this one.

All the other deletes for metadefs return 204.  This call is doc'd to return a 204.  So if I wrote a script for this, I'd expect it to return a 204.  I write my script, test it, and discover that the call does not return a 204, it returns a 200.  Now what should I as a script writer do in this case?

(1) Change my code to expect a 200 (and only a 200) in this situation

(2) Change my code to act as if response code R, where 200 <= R < 300, reports success

Have you come across this situation in real life?  I certainly have.  Which of the above choices did you make?

I'm going to drop to +1 so on one merges this by mistake before the discussion concludes, but I'm not convinced that this is a bad change.

Patch Set 2:

Ken'ichi Ohmichi wrote:

> I was really surprised by this patch. This change seems don't take
> care of APPs which check current status code(200) as its success
> operation at all. This is really backwards incompatible changes
> without any notification, and it is possible to affect its
> interoperability.

I was really surprised by how condescending this review was. (Hint: Saying "I was really surprised by ..." is condescending)

Per the API WG guidelines than Ghanshyam and Dharini linked, this is acceptable per:

    Changing an error response code to be more accurate.

This is *more* accurate. There's no response body *and* it's already documented as a 204 and has been for a while. The fact that it hasn't been a 204 is an oversight.

Further as someone who interacts with APIs I tend to check the range if the code doesn't match and then report it.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I have thought about this and am restoring my original +2.

It does not make sense to prioritize an implicit contract over an explicit, published contract, which is what, by objecting to this patch, you are asking us to do.

Let me say that again, because it appears that the message is not getting through.  This is not a case of an undocumented API where a consumer must learn by inference how it behaves.  No, this is a case in which there is a published API reference document that explains what is supposed to happen in this specific case.  It does not make sense to prioritize an implicit contract over the explicit, published contract.

Think of it this way.  What about the nice guys, who follow the rules, who read the api-ref and have written scripts expecting to receive a 204 for deleting a metadefs tag, as the documentation states, but have never actually needed, up to this point, to delete a metadefs tag?  (Apparently they haven't tested their scripts, but I said they were nice, not great software engineers.  And apparently the hypothetical engineers expecting 200s who Ken and Steve are so worried about are not that great either, since no one has filed a bug about this issue prior to a few days ago.  Or, as I suggested in my previous comment, the engineers who noticed have coded their scripts to look for a 2xx range response.)  Why is it OK to break the untested scripts of the nice guys by suddenly returning a 200 they won't be prepared for?  Thus, *not* merging this patch is just as much a breaking change as merging it.  Therefore, it makes sense to respect the published contract in the api-ref and make this change.

Further, I must point out that the API Stability Guidelines are not a trump card that can be invoked to squash any change.  As they specifically state, they are guidelines (not a mandatory policy), and in fact, all the recommendations are qualified by "generally acceptable" and "generally not acceptable".  And further, if the examples given in that document are to be cited as a reason to reject a change, the situations must analogous.  Let me repeat that, because that message doesn't appear to be getting through, either.  The cited situation must be analogous in relevant ways, or an argument by analogy to reject this change because some other change has been rejected, is not a sound argument.

In this particular situation, the example "Adding new header OK; changing response code not so much" would seem to apply.  Upon closer examination, however, the discussion in that bug concerns changing the response code to something that makes more sense or is more RESTful--there's no mention of what the documentation (if any) defined as the success response code for that call.  Thus, the situation is not analogous to what we are considering here, where:

(1) All the delete-metadefs-* calls, as specifically stated in the documentation, return a 204 upon success.

(2) The documentation specifically states that the delete-metadefs-tag call should return a 204 upon success.

(3) The delete-metadefs-tag is returning a 200 with no response body upon success.

(4) All the other delete-metadefs-* calls do in fact return a 204 upon success.

Ian is not proposing to make this change simply because the 204 success response makes more sense than returning a 200, but because, given items (1)-(4) above, it is an obvious bug.

OK, so you are worried about who could be broken by this change.  Let's consider that more carefully.  The set of people this change may break consists of:

(A) People who have hard-coded an expectation of a 200

(B) People who have hard-coded an expectation of a 204

(Note that I'm not including (C), the people who noticed the discrepancy, and coded appropriately (as I suggested on my previous comment).  People in set (C) won't be broken by this change.)

Why is it OK to break the nice guy users (B) who are following the published contract, but not OK to break users (A)?

Clearly, in this case, someone is going to get broken.  Thus we need to make an informed decision about who this will be, based upon relevant contextual factors, that is, points (1)-(4) above plus the observation that we should take into account future users, who of course, will be much better served by a consistent, easily learnable, API.

To sum up, I find the argument against this change unconvincing and I am surprised that someone would make it.  But I recognize that we don't all think alike, so I do welcome this discussion so that we can work this out for the benefit of future stackers.  My conclusion, however, is that this is an appropriate change.

Patch Set 2:

Hi Brian,

 > (A) People who have hard-coded an expectation of a 200 (Based on the code - oomichi)
 > (B) People who have hard-coded an expectation of a 204 (Based on the api-ref doc - oomichi)
 >
 > Why is it OK to break the nice guy users (B) who are following
 > the published contract, but not OK to break users (A)?

That is a nice point.
If we found this bug and fixed it in the same dev cycle when implementing the code, I am not against this change so strongly.
However, this tags resource has been implemented since Dec 18/2014 with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/133874 , we have published it over 2 years. Then we have a lot  of users who use it.
I don't think we have a lot of users (B) because such APPs cannot run on actual clouds at all because the status code which is returned from servers is different.
Most users want APPs which can run actually instead of the specification base, then we have a lot of users (A).
I just want to make them safe.

I really can understand we want to fix this kind of problems based on the code as developers, and Nova also has a lot of this kind of problems and we can see them by 'grep TODO * | grep 20' under nova/api/openstack/compute:

 admin_password.py:    # TODO(eliqiao): Here should be 204(No content) instead of 202 by v2.1+
 agents.py:    # TODO(oomichi): Here should be 204(No Content) instead of 200 by v2.1
 agents.py:    # TODO(oomichi): Here should be 201(Created) instead of 200 by v2.1
 evacuate.py:    # TODO(eliqiao): Should be responding here with 202 Accept
 quota_sets.py:    # TODO(oomichi): Here should be 204(No Content) instead of 202 by v2.1
 rescue.py:    # TODO(cyeoh): Should be responding here with 202 Accept
 volumes.py:    # TODO(mriedem): This API should return a 202 instead of a 200 response.

However we cannot do that due to backwards incompatibility.
For whole OpenStack projects and ecosystem, Glance is super important component and it should be *stable*. Glance is core of cores and is Layer 1 component of OpenStack layers[1].
Today we cannot imagine OpenStack clouds without Glance. Then we (QA-team) takes care of its stability so much like this review.

[1]: https://dague.net/2014/08/26/openstack-as-layers/

Patch Set 2:

Ian

 > This is *more* accurate. There's no response body *and* it's
 > already documented as a 204 and has been for a while.

I know it because the corresponding api-wg guideline is proposed by me with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/158179/
And you put +1 on that, and I respect your knowledge about the REST API design so much.
I just am against backwards incompatible change only.

Patch Set 2:

 > > I was really surprised by this patch. This change seems don't
 > take
 > > care of APPs which check current status code(200) as its success
 > > operation at all. This is really backwards incompatible changes
 > > without any notification, and it is possible to affect its
 > > interoperability.

 > I was really surprised by how condescending this review was. (Hint:
 > Saying "I was really surprised by ..." is condescending)
 > 
 > Per the API WG guidelines than Ghanshyam and Dharini linked, this
 > is acceptable per:
 > 
 > Changing an error response code to be more accurate.
 > 
 > This is *more* accurate. There's no response body *and* it's
 > already documented as a 204 and has been for a while. The fact that
 > it hasn't been a 204 is an oversight.
 > 
 > Further as someone who interacts with APIs I tend to check the
 > range if the code doesn't match and then report it.

Ian, we were trying to change the success response code, not the error response code.

Patch Set 2:

I think this is important discussion, I push https://review.openstack.org/#/c/422264 for getting feedback from more wide area.

Patch Set 2:

Dharini Chandrasekar

Yep, you are right.
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/evaluating_api_changes.html#guidance says clearly this is not acceptable according to:

 The following types of changes are generally not considered acceptable:
    Changing which response code is returned on success.

Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Dharini explained that I misread the Guidelines. I probably hadn't had enough coffee. =)

I'm not going to withdraw this, as I've been strenuously asked not to, but for now I'm going to mark it as a WIP.

Patch Set 2:

According to ttx in the thread about the api-compatibility tag and updating the guidelines about changes, following the change guidelines is optional:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-January/110898.html

So it seems that maybe what all the discussion within glance is about is whether or not the project wants to subscribe those guidelines. If they do not, then that's how it is. If they do...

Patch Set 2:

@Chris: I think it's a bit more complicated than that.

Let's forget about the image visibility change as that's in the past and was hopefully a pathological singular point.

Glance wants to be a good OpenStack citizen, given its current role in the overall OpenStack ecosystem.  Since you pretty much have to have Glance, if Glance is continually breaking its API, it's going to hurt OpenStack for all the reasons Sean outlined on the ML, even if other projects like Nova are completely stable.  So I think it makes sense for Glance to follow the guidelines.

But if the guidelines aren't black-and-white, we need to have a clear procedure for how things are decided.  For example, the current guidelines don't cover this patch.  (See my comment above, the one restoring my +2, for my argument for that claim.  It's true that there's a patch up for the guidelines that would make this patch unacceptable under the guidelines, but that cuts both ways (i.e., this patch could be a reason to reject that one).)

To at least some of the developers, this seems like a straightforward bugfix ... this one call is behaving differently from all the relevant similar calls, plus it was documented to behave the same as the other calls.  If we were on the receiving end of this, i.e., expecting to get a 204 because that's what the docs said (and that's what all the other metedefs delete calls return upon success), but getting a 200, we'd write code that checked for a 2xx range and file a bug.  It seems kind of counterintuitive to fix this by changing the docs (especially since we should flag this in the docs as being an unusual success response and unlike all the other calls).

On the other hand, if the policy is no changing response codes, ever, then we'll respect that.  I'm just holding this up to make sure we've looked at one of the corner cases before adopting that policy.

Anyway, we'd like to fix this in Ocata, one way or another.

Patch Set 2:

I am fixing this bug with https://review.openstack.org/425487

Patch Set 5:

I too +1 to have microversion in glance, that will solve the lot of problem and easy scope to improve APIs.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Since this is endorsed by API-WG and the TC, it makes more sense to be uniform with the other metadef deletes response status codes than change the doc to show a not-so-right status code.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

My only change was updating the commit message, so I feel OK approving this with me as committer.

Patch Set 5:

I thought the results of that community discussion was that we could NOT change API response codes like this. That is a change in the API and would therefore require a microversion, and it was deemed overkill to do a microversion bump just to make a code "more correct".

FWIW, we do not allow this in Cinder.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1
